The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.
An A-module M is said to be finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators. It is also referred to as a finite A-module.
Does the concept of a/an Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Finitely generated module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a 'Domain' as defined here pertains to the domain of a function, which is a set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. This concept is primarily used in the context of functions in mathematics, particularly in analysis and algebra.

On the other hand, a 'Finitely generated module' is a concept from algebra that deals with modules over a ring. A module M over a ring A is finitely generated if there exists a finite set of elements in M that generate the entire module through linear combinations with coefficients in A.

The definition of a finitely generated module does not inherently require the concept of a domain of a function. It is concerned with algebraic structures (modules and rings) rather than functions and their domains. Therefore, understanding or defining a finitely generated module does not depend on the concept of the domain of a function.
